title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
This is the first AAA game I ever bought for which I surely can say its a bad game.

Its simply weak. I don't see how this can be enjoyable after 1 and 2. So many weird limits and choices in development that make no sense. Not lack of development, but straight up restrictions that make the game less fun (can't change weapons, can't buy cars, extremely boring and limited hacking).

Even without playing the previous 2 games, it overall has a pretty bad feeling. The cyberpunk elements don't really fit into the world, they stick out like a sore thumb. 

Voice acting is awful, and general writing gets worse the more you play. The whole point is that there is no main character, you just switch between them. But the characters can't even cooperate on missions and they almost never interact, so you basically just switch between characters with different skills (and the skills arent so amazingly different that you care to play more than 1-2 characters).

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
i wish i could get refund on this game. 
a boring game, a totally downgrade from watch dogs 2, bad parkour, bad voice acting, bad gameplay, too many bugs, bad character design (all women are super ugly), a total disrespect to watch dogs franchise 
i never buy anything from bugysoft again

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review: Buy Watch Dogs 1 or 2. Not this absolute dogwater game. The DLC is remotely redeemable but even then it's just the game foundation that ruins it all. Played it on day 1 and after all this time this game still kinda fucking sucks. Gameplay is very janky, story looked like it was written by a disgruntled redditor and the monetization is just something else. Just play the other 2 games, this one is just a soulless cashgrab, don't be fooled by sales and reviews.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review: As a big WatchDogs fan I must say, Legion is quite disappointing.It’s a decent game on its own, but as part of the franchise it’s certainly the weakest. The story took the wrong turn somewhere, dropping the lore and themes of the first two games completely, plus lots of gameplay features which made the first two games stand out were dropped completely.It just isn't WatchDogs anymore.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
Story – 6/10 - Overall not too much of a breathtaking story. The story could get quite repetitive, not something that is too crazy. An average story. 

Mechanics – 9/10 - Really solid mechanics. Things like unlocking new tech, parkour, and the seamless hacking throughout the game is very smooth and enjoyable, lovely mechanics. 

Characters – 6/10 - Had a few great characters like Wrench and Aiden. 

Controls – 7/10 - Great smooth controls. No complaints. 

Graphics – 8/10 - Beautiful graphics that really capture London. Was also able to run this game with great performance. All High settings running at around 70-80 FPS. 

Music – 4/10 - The soundtrack didn't exactly stick out, had some decent songs on the radio. Nothing special. 

Pacing – 4/10 - Felt like a drag at some points and pacing didn't seem too consistent. 

Setting – 8/10 - Love the setting in London. Very beautiful and well captured. 

Missions – 5/10 - Main missions and side missions were repetitive and didn’t really have too much to them. Usually just shooting shit up or being stealthy. Had some good missions though, certain ones. 

Overall Thoughts / Rating – 6.3/10 - Overall the main things that stuck out to me in Watch Dogs Legions were the mechanics and setting. I loved the hacking mechanics, parkour, the fact you can literally be anyone on the street and gunplay, and the setting of London was beautiful. Had a great character, Wrench. The actual story, missions, and pacing were nothing special. Overall enjoyed this game, and love the Watch Dogs franchise.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
This game is not really bad, but sometimes we have to repeat the same mission in side missions and in main missions. BTW The story is really good so I don't care about the other stuff. 
9/10 for the game.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review: Hard to beat watchdogs 2 a masterpiece but legions inst to far behind if your looking for graphics and a throwback to some Easter eggs and characters from w-dogs 1 and 2 get the season pass If you want a good combat system.. ehh w-dogs 2 may be better but the game itself is in! this game i liked a lot from first pics and wanted to test it i got the ultimate ed for 28 dollars on a huge sale i would argue that the 60 for the games is a bit much its an amped up kinda cramped city but wow could i recruit and i recruited grandmas blew up cars and even knocked out grandmas so i found this game real good not w-dogs 2 good though if your looking for an intense version of this w-dogs 2 is for you if you have never played and watchdogs before this is a good step to get you running into the franchise.

review:
The visuals, costume and location design are cool! 
Everything else is shit. 

The mechanics suck. The physics of hitting, riding and walking - shit. The voice acting and lisping sucks. Textures and graphics suck. It's impossible to play. 2/10

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
Lost interest in this game after about 15 hours. Gets too repetetive too quickly. 
Cons
- crashes regularly, sometimes 10 min after launch, sometimes I can play 4+ hours, of my 10 last steam games this one is by far the worst
- they reuse locations already after first 5 missions or so
- bugs: once a car to be stolen stood there upside down, not drivable, had to leave location far enough and return in order for the "scene" to "reload"
- gameplay issues: one of your tasks is to recruit new operatives and that's supposed to be a lot of fun; but this is useless because the game points out skilled people on the map, so you exaclty know the best candidates to approach
- logical issues: there are security cameras all over, but they do you no harm, they don't react to you at all; but you can hack them, chain the camera hacks and that way sometimes fulfil your mission goal without setting a foot into the restricted area; it feels like the cameras are YOUR security asset put into EVERY enemy location, it feels very stupid to me
- the only thing you can do with the money you earn is to style up your operatives and weapons
- there is no character development at all and the uprade system (gear/hacks) is too thin
- map a bit too small for my taste
- all in all a big step back in comparison to watch dogs 2
- lot more minor things but they add up

Pros
- graphics are nice, London looks really cool
- darts minigame was fun

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review: This is one of my top 20 games of all time and one of my most played (with a few hundred hours on playstation before playing the steam version.) If you really dig into the profiler and treat this game like more of an RPG than straight stealth-action the new character generator adds a layer of immersiveness that has never been matched. Unfortunately, the lack of a first person mode and some jankiness with the cutscenes takes away from some of that & there are some problems with the gameplay that others have covered enough for me not to get into it. 4.2 / 5 -- and I have high hopes for wd 3/4

title: Watch Dogs: Legion

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
It's an open world game with lots of variations and lots of things to be explored.
Even the characters you choose to recruit have a variety of abilities to suit your playing style.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review: I think this is a pretty good game especially for me who likes character customization. And the setting selection that Ubisoft made in choosing London is very interesting. But it is very unfortunate that Ubisoft abandoned this game, I am quite disappointed with that.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review: The recruiting part of this game is very unique, and fun. I enjoyed putting together a team with people from all parts of the map. While the gameplay wasn't amazing, it didn't get too boring because there was enough of a variety of strategies to make each mission seem a little different. There were a couple bugs that crashed the game, but it didn't happen too often. All around it's worth a try just to play around with recruiting.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review: It's interesting that you can build a team of hackers with different traits. You can switch between your team members based on skills or equipment needed for a mission. There is still a story even though you don't have a specific protagonist but it feels well done. The tech tools from the first game have been expanded a little further. I'm liking the game roughly as much as I enjoyed the first two games in the series.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
Watch Dogs: Legion is certainly an interesting premise for a game, but it unfortunately fails to live up to it's potential, therefore I can't recommend it.

Just play the first two games instead; they're vastly superior.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
I'm writing this review at a time when [i]Ubisoft[/i] is facing some difficult days.

[i]Yves Guillemot[/i] is grappling with troubles, shares are hovering at $9, and shareholders are sounding the alarm. The release of Shadows has been pushed back to February, but it’s unlikely that will give the game much of a lifeline. There’s speculation that Guillemot may be orchestrating a drop in [i]Ubisoft’s[/i] stock price to consolidate a controlling stake. Regardless, I went ahead and picked up a few dozen shares while the opportunity presents itself.

As for [b]Watch Dogs: Legion[/b]—it's not so bad. It's worth the $5 sale price. The city is fantastic, especially when you're racing through it in the rain, the sky dimmed by a murky orange sunset, neon signs flickering in puddles below. Sure, the NPCs are dumb as bricks, and the missions lack originality, but I’m looking at this from an architectural angle. And futuristic London? It’s genuinely a marvel.

At its core, what you're getting for this price is a pack of assets simulating a city of the future. The details stand out, particularly when compared with [i]Assassin's Creed Syndicate[/i]. Essentially, [i]Ubisoft[/i] is shuffling players through different time periods, and this journey costs less than a budget flight on Wizz Air, Ryanair, or EasyJet.

Everything else about the game is, frankly, terrible. The story? Naah. The enemy AI? Laughable. The character customization? So poorly done that you have no idea who to pick by default. The soundtrack? Middle-of-the-road at best. Cut scenes? Awful. The voice acting, unfortunately, feels mismatched—poorly chosen voices that don’t suit the default characters, with dialogue that doesn’t quite sync with the lip movements.

We’ll see what becomes of the Guillemot brothers’ legacy. For now, the quality of products leaves much to be desired.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
Watch Dogs: Legion is an ambitious and exhilarating entry in the Watch Dogs franchise. Set in a beautifully rendered near-future London, the game stands out for its unique "Play as Anyone" system, which allows you to recruit and control any NPC in the world. This mechanic is a true game-changer, providing endless possibilities for creative gameplay, and making each playthrough feel fresh and personal.

The variety of characters you can recruit—from hackers to construction workers to grandmas—brings a fun, dynamic element to missions. Each character comes with their own set of skills, traits, and personalities, offering new strategies for tackling objectives. The game encourages experimentation, and there’s a real sense of accomplishment when you figure out how to use a seemingly unorthodox recruit to complete a mission.

London itself is gorgeously crafted, blending iconic landmarks with dystopian flair. The attention to detail in the environments, combined with a compelling storyline that tackles relevant themes of surveillance, authoritarianism, and resistance, gives the game both depth and immediacy.

The missions are well-designed, offering a mix of stealth, combat, and hacking challenges. Whether you're infiltrating a corporate stronghold or liberating a borough from an oppressive regime, the game rewards ingenuity and adaptability. The inclusion of cooperative multiplayer further extends the game's replayability, letting you team up with friends to cause chaos or complete objectives.

Overall, Watch Dogs: Legion is a thrilling and innovative experience that brings new life to open-world games. Its emphasis on player freedom, combined with a rich setting and engaging story, makes it a must-play for fans of the genre and newcomers alike.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review: I don't suggest playing this unless you enjoy rebooting your game every 10 minutes. It loves to crash, and I mean LOVES to crash. I have tried everything from updating drivers to turning down settings. It doesn't matter, the game still kills my graphics drivers and causes windows to stutter. Do not buy this rubbish, get Watch Dogs 1 & 2 instead. Better story, better animations, less bugs and crashes. I got this on discount and still regret the money I wasted.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
Watch Dogs Legion is an interesting insight into a dystopian city that has fallen down the rabbit hole and nobody seems to find a way out. First of all, the innovative (albeit a bit flawed) Play As Anyone mechanic introduced in the video game allows players to recruit virtually any non-playable character in the open world, each bringing unique skills, backgrounds, and personalities to the fight against oppression. The roleplaying implications are vast, as you can immerse yourself in the lives of everyday Londoners, from construction workers and cryptocurrency analysts to paramedics and pickpockets, shifting your playstyle with each character. This mechanic encourages creative approaches to missions (in the simplest possible ways if you so desire) and fosters a deep connection to the individuals you recruit, making the rebellion against authoritarianism feel truly communal and diverse.

The factions in Watch Dogs Legion paint a vivid picture of the powers at play in dystopian London. DedSec, the group you belong to, is a grassroots resistance trying to free the city from the grip of oppressive organizations. Albion, a private military contractor, enforces martial law, symbolizing the rise of corporate-controlled security forces. Clan Kelley operates in the shadows, profiting off of London's underworld through human trafficking and black market deals. Meanwhile, the Signals Intelligence Response Service (SIRS), the intelligence agency, wields control over mass surveillance, presenting a chilling representation of how governments can abuse technology for control. Each faction not only serves as a formidable antagonist but also represents a different aspect of totalitarian rule, from corporate to criminal to governmental.

Skye Larsen's story arc encapsulates the game's exploration of transhumanism, pushing the boundaries of what it means to be human. As the visionary behind advanced artificial intelligence and the leader of Project Daybreak (a project that aims to upload human consciousness into machines), Skye Larsen's ambitions raise ethical questions about identity, mortality, and the price of immortality. Her storyline serves as the darkest example of how technology in the wrong hands can dehumanize and exploit life itself. Skye Larsen's character and her experiments on her own family force players to confront the ethical nightmare of playing God, making her one of the most disturbing and tragic figures in Watch Dogs Legion.

London, as reimagined in Watch Dogs Legion, is a masterclass in world-building, capturing the essence of the city while painting it in a dystopian light. Iconic landmarks such as the Tower of London, Camden Market, and Westminster Abbey are seamlessly integrated into a future where drones, surveillance cameras, and propaganda posters are omnipresent. The streets feel alive with the tension of a city under siege, from graffiti depicting resistance movements and Albion Contractors arresting innocent civilians in the streets after an identity check to automated checkpoints manned by Albion drones and Clan Kelley Associates harassing citizens to enforce their authority in controlled territories. This version of London feels both familiar and unsettling, a city at once modern and trapped under the weight of technological authoritarianism.

The documents scattered throughout the video game's open world and various missions enrich the narrative, giving players deeper insight into the lives of both the oppressors and the oppressed. Audio logs, text files, relics and dialogues reveal the motivations behind the factions, the corruption within the system, and the personal stories of those suffering under Albion and Clan Kelley's rule. These collectibles add layers to the main plot, providing context to major events and fleshing out characters who might otherwise seem one-dimensional or who don't even appear in the video game but played a crucial role in illustrating the violence in a dangerous dystopian London. Collecting these pieces of hidden lore rewards players with a fuller understanding of the world and the true stakes of DedSec's fight for freedom.

Watch Dogs Legion, as a narrative video game (if you have this approach in mind when playing it), is a powerful reminder that in the face of overwhelming oppression, it is not just heroes who rise up, but everyday people who are united in the belief that together, they can reclaim their future.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
[h2]Watch Dogs Legion[/h2]
[h3][i] Hard to Resist[/i][/h3]
This is one of those rare games that had me hooked from start to finish, and even then I wanted more. It's an ingenious game with no true protagonist that makes you grow emotionally attached to procedurally-generated NPCs, of all things. Although you do have to run through the obstacle of Ubisoft's online DRM, this is a rare Ubisoft gem that's actually worth it.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
A nice dreamy representation of a 'Cyberpunk' London, a bit further into the future. 

Nice story, forgettable characters as anyone can be recruited as a main character, from young podcasters, to elderly crypto-miners. 

Annoying bit is when at the end of a campaign mission where you need to escape and the character 'dies'; as you don't have a save system, you will have to take over another character, you get a mission completed sign without being able to retry. The other character get's into prison/hospital and you need to wait (usually) 15 IRL minutes to be able to deploy again. If you can role-play into these characters, it's great, however sometimes they just can't themselves. I had a spy who in a mission with speaking to other spies and acted completely clueless on what spies are doing. Also voices acting is quite bad, silent protagonists would have been so much more enjoyable.

Other than that I had a blast, great game. No achievements unfortunately so I didn't invest in collecting everything.

(Played on Steam Deck, runs great, couple of crashes here and there but smooth enough. Eats the battery though and you need the Ubisoft launcher to start)

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review: Car driving mechanics is ass. Hacking mechanics was better in first 2 games. Character dialogues are so cringy i uninstalled the game. I only played the Bloodline DLC from start to finish. Aiden Pearce is really giving an uncle vibes which is cool BUT a man who destroyed all of the Blume is having ethical meltdowns after he came to the place from a stolen vehicle??? Just funny. However Wrench was really cool. It's hard to mess up that awesome character. But main game was boring as f*ck.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
1/4

Chracters are ugly, uninteresting start and the first 1, 2 and group of enemies all glitched. My crosshair was on their heads and the bullets were going everywhere but their heads. The AI voice is not bad, but completely out of sync when we compare it to every other voice.

Storywise, this is a massive downgrade from Watch Dogs 2.

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
Watch Dogs: Legion Review - 4.5/5 Stars

Watch Dogs: Legion is an incredible open-world game that pushes the boundaries of what's possible in the genre. It offers a unique "Play as Anyone" mechanic that allows you to recruit and control any NPC in the game, each with their own abilities and backstory. This innovation adds a layer of depth and strategy, making each mission feel fresh and exciting.

The detailed cityscape, combined with engaging hacking gameplay, creates an immersive experience that feels both dynamic and alive. Whether you're stealthily infiltrating a building or leading a full-scale assault, the freedom to choose your approach keeps the gameplay endlessly enjoyable.

While the story could benefit from a bit more depth, and there are occasional technical hiccups, It's still an amazing game give it a try!

title: Watch Dogs: Legion
review:
Got it on sale, and honestly? I got my money's worth so far.

I'm 24 hours in at the time of this review and I haven't touched the main story at all outside of the tutorial missions. Maybe it's just that I enjoy the mind-numbing make-your-own-fun kind of content, makes my monkey brain go brrrrrrr clearing out the map or recruiting a halfway decent looking character. If you don't like repetitive gameplay or if you want a deeply engaging story, look elsewhere. But it's great for someone like me that just wants a game to just mentally check out and chill out with.

Maybe I'll run into a gamebreaking bug or have my save corrupted and change my review, but so far-- it's just been a decent experience. Nothing life-changing, but for 8 dollars, I could do a LOT worse.
